title: geth starts resyncing even after the full sync is complete .
body:
Hi there,

Please note that this is an issue tracker reserved for bug reports and feature requests.

For general questions please use the gitter channel or the Ethereum stack exchange at https://ethereum.stackexchange.com.

#### System information

Geth version: ` 1.9.5-stable`
OS & Version: CentOS Linux release 7.6.1810 
Commit hash : (if `develop`)

#### Expected behaviour
After the fast sync is complete the latest block from ropsten bootnodes should be synced  .

#### Actual behaviour
Geth starts syncing again even though it already has the  latest block details 
PFA the logs .
If we restart geth it reads from disk and starts syncing from the latest block .

[ geth_logs.log](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/files/3684740/geth_logs.log)

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
sync to ropsten from scratch without restart 

#### Backtrace

````
[backtrace]
````
Whoah, that's funky. Definitely should not have done that.

Encountered this again on restart this time it was due to missing head chain PFB  
```

INFO [10-03|06:36:32.040] Importing heavy sidechain segment        blocks=2048 start=8193 end=10240
INFO [10-03|06:36:34.492] Imported new chain segment               blocks=2048 txs=77  mgas=32.112 elap
```

From what I can tell from the first log-file, this is what happens. 
It does a fast-sync, to `6492699`
```
INFO [10-02|17:55:46.313] Committed new head block                 number=6492699 hash=31fe6d…85eb2b
```
Then imports some remaining blocks on top, until `6492816`
```
INFO [10-02|17:55:51.779] Imported new chain segment               blocks=115 txs=2686 mgas=228.939 elapsed=5.410s    mgasps=42.317 number=6492814 hash=b66fdc…cc8264 dirty=10.65MiB
INFO [10-02|17:55:53.011] Imported new chain segment               blocks=2   txs=25   mgas=1.008   elapsed=38.896ms  mgasps=25.915 number=6492816 hash=b1e95f…15fff6 dirty=10.76MiB
INFO [10-02|17:55:53.011] Fast sync complete, auto disabling
```
Simultaneously, it finds out about a sidechain, and imports some of that
```
INFO [10-02|17:55:56.391] Sidechain written to disk                start=6485846 end=6485851 sidetd=23351892562934351 localtd=23353321757165960
INFO [10-02|17:55:56.972] Sidechain written to disk                start=6485852 end=6485858 sidetd=23351908709003239 localtd=23353321757165960
```
Sidechain appears to be `6485846` to `6485852`. At this point, I think it discovers that the sidechain is indeed longer than the chain it's currently at. So it needs to switch over. However, block `6485846` is earlier than our pivot block `6492699`, so the only place where we have a `state`, is genesis. So it uses that: 

Starting at block `1`, importing blocks one by one:
```
INFO [10-02|18:06:00.673] Importing heavy sidechain segment        blocks=2048  start=1       end=2048
INFO [10-02|18:06:02.853] Imported new chain segment               blocks=2048  txs=22   mgas=1.258   elapsed=2.177s    mgasps=0.578  number=2048    hash=6708aa…742bab age=2y10mo3w   dirty=10.95MiB
```

@amanpruthi I recommend that you start over, and this time use the cmd line flag `--whitelist=6485846=0x43f0cd1e5b1f9c4d5cda26c240b59ee4f1b510d0a185aa8fd476d091b0097a80`

That flag makes your node issue a challenge to peers, checking that the block `6485846` is indeed the Istanbul block, and not the non-forked chain. That should 'solve' your problem going forward, but there are underlying issues which we need to fix aswell, as documented in #20150

Thanks @holiman .I tried cleaning data dir and starting sync from scratch again and faced this issue  again .I am trying again lets see if I am able to succeed .Is there  other solution so that I can proceed?

> I tried cleaning data dir and starting sync from scratch again and faced this issue again

hmm.. Please clarify -- did you use `--whitelist=6485846=0x43f0cd1e5b1f9c4d5cda26c240b59ee4f1b510d0a185aa8fd476d091b0097a80` _and_ had the same issue again?
Nope did not use this option .Is there a compiled  list of blocks for which I should do this ? .In any case will update you after using this option .
Just an update as soon as I added the flag   --whitelist=6485846=0x43f0cd1e5b1f9c4d5cda26c240b59ee4f1b510d0a185aa8fd476d091b0097a80  geth started syncing from latest block and is in sync now .Thanks

> Is there a compiled list of blocks for which I should do this ?

No. It can be seen as an emergency procedure to use when there are long (invalid) sidechains, but you specifically know what chain you want to hone in on, and ignore other forks
